text:
Hi guys, I'm looking at some PRO data and I would like to get a snapshot of the market at a particular point in time. Currently my approach is to load the data into a BFLW historical generator stream, and then check the timestamp of every single market book in the generator until I reach the one I'm interested in.
This is proving to be very slow (like 2 hours to run a month of data). I'm wondering whether there is a much smarter way to achieve what I am trying to do?

elements.text:
Hi guys, I'm looking at some PRO data and I would like to get a snapshot of the market at a particular point in time. Currently my approach is to load the data into a BFLW historical generator stream, and then check the timestamp of every single market book in the generator until I reach the one I'm interested in.
This is proving to be very slow (like 2 hours to run a month of data). I'm wondering whether there is a much smarter way to achieve what I am trying to do?

text:
Are you using lightweight mode? What are you after in the book? Might be quicker to manually read the files.

Alternative is also the Rust library

text: <@U4H19D1D2> I know we've got "seconds_to_start" but it would really save time on some backtesting to be able to skip the stream forwards to a point rather than keep ignoring packets until the market close point when you find out the winner. Skipping to the first packet after a time, or a state such as suspended or closed would be ideal. Football from early opening to final whistle is probably worst case for backtestimg time I guess. Hopefully you might tell me there's already a way to do this ...

text: I actually don't understand what you mean by 'when you find out the winner`

elements.text: I actually don't understand what you mean by 'when you find out the winner`

text: I'm meaning that the strategy PL for the market is not known until you get to the final packet and process_closed_market is called - then the runner book has a status of winner/loser. So if you only put bets in say the morning market it's a lot of data to chunder through to get the final outcome. Having made me think about that though, the matching has got to be simulated and MOC catered for etc so I'm not sure the suggestion had any merit now :joy:

elements.text: I'm meaning that the strategy PL for the market is not known until you get to the final packet and process_closed_market is called - then the runner book has a status of winner/loser. text:
Oh so you want to set a start and end

`seconds_to_start: (30, 0)`

`seconds_since_start: (0, 300)`

elements.text: Oh so you want to set a start and end
seconds_to_start: (30, 0)
seconds_since_start: (0, 300)

text: If you've already read the whole file into memory, use a search algo to find the start point rather than doing it in o(n) time

elements.text: If you've already read the whole file into memory, use a search algo to find the start point rather than doing it in o(n) time

text: reading the whole file into memory takes 3x longer than what I was doing before :slightly_smiling_face:

text: it seems like the best you can do is use lightweight=True and then multiprocessing.

elements.text: it seems like the best you can do is use lightweight=True and then multiprocessing.

text: qq Im just about to submit a rquest to have an account raised from the standard 200 market streaming limit to 1000 (or higher if possible). Is the correct way to move forward with this by contacting betfair through the developer support page, and submit a request at <https://support.developer.betfair.com/hc/en-us/requests/new> for said increase? Thanks

text:
<@U4H19D1D2> my base strategy has params like these which are checked for each packet in check_market_book() so can dip in quickly (eg) 5 hours before, place any bets and then ignore all data until market complete. But, since simulation has to check matching the only chance to skip to end would be once all bets were matched - all a bit too complex to bother with I now think.
```startAtSeconds = 18000    # seconds before official start to begin strategy
stopAtSeconds = 17995     # when to stop strategy ie start time - this : set -ve to carry on beyond official start```

elements.text: my base strategy has params like these which are checked for each packet in check_market_book() so can dip in quickly (eg) 5 hours before, place any bets and then ignore all data until market complete. But, since simulation has to check matching the only chance to skip to end would be once all bets were matched - all a bit too complex to bother with I now think.

startAtSeconds = 18000    # seconds before official start to begin strategy
stopAtSeconds = 17995     # when to stop strategy ie start time - this : set -ve to carry on beyond official start

text:
Hello. What's the most flumine-y way of checking across another market? Subscribed to market X and when something happens, check market Y for status/price/whatever. 

Couldn't see an example in the docs/search so thought I'd ask :)

Couldn't see an example in the docs/search so thought I'd ask :)
